title: What Champs do you want to hear more about?
body:
Hi guys,

I wanted to jump in and ask which Champions (or regions, events, storylines, etc related to their backgrounds) you reaaaaally want to see / learn more about.

As Jaredan and others have mentioned in other threads, in addition to ongoing new Champ / ChamUp support we're currently focused on developing things like world building, longer storylines, R+D, etc. Nevertheless, going back and developing the stories and backgrounds of the characters we all love – and fixing things that are just broken from a narrative point of view – is really important to us. The stories for many champs need some love, and we want you guys to have a voice in helping us determine where we need to focus our attention.

A couple caveats to set expectations:

* This isn't a promise to drop everything and focus on fleshing out your favorite champ's background (at least not yet) straight away. Having said that, if there are some clear favorites among players around the world, then we’d like that to factor into our decision-making process.

* Please don’t offer up specific story ideas – legally, we just can’t use them (the same reason I don’t read fan-fic – it’s a can of worms from a legal POV).

* Also, I can't promise exactly when or how we’ll be able to deliver on this stuff. Despite the best intentions, we've burned ourselves before by making overzealous promises, so we’d rather not go down that route.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

Cheers!

Tell me he isn't going the way of {{champion:101}} or {{champion:48}}, tell me he isn't being written as a Satudray-morning cartoon villain. I want my possibly insane, genuinely interested in improving humanity, transhuman scientist who has become so disconnected from humanity he has difficulty understanding what would be in mankind's best interest.

This.  Jayce's lore made Viktor seem far more 'cartoonishly evil' than his own lore even came close to hinting at him being.  Until that point he seemed obsessed with his ideas, but he meant no ill will towards humanity.  He was a brilliant scientist, but Stanwick's betrayal meant that he lost everything he had worked for.  He still wanted to make the world a better place, but now his goals had changed.  He came to the conclusion that the only way to improve the world was to improve humanity.  Machines are perfect.  They are not bound by human flaws and weaknesses, and if man could become like machines, then man too could be perfect.  There is no need to consider adapting through the Glorious Evolution a loss of one's humanity, it is simply wanting to become a better human.  

With Jayce's lore Viktor essentially became the very thing his own lore showed he hated:  Someone that steals others' ideas/projects for their own gain.  He stole the crystal, defeated Jayce's security, then went back to Zaun.  By the time Jayce came to retrieve the crystal, Viktor had already put it to use in his labs, but the fact that he and his acolytes were unable to even stop one man shows a weakness that was never implied in his original lore.  Before the removal of the Institute of War, it was Viktor's augmentations to his own form that impressed the Summoners enough to grant him access into the League of Legends.  They thought he was worthy of taking on monsters and other incredibly strong opponents, with only his own technology to aid him.  While it's true that Jayce was also injured when he fled Zaun after destroying the crystal, the fact that Viktor was defeated in his own labs made it seem like his character was fundamentally changed into something both mentally and physically weaker just to make Jayce seem like a 'good guy.'  

Viktor is such an interesting and complex character, but apart from the promos for the Battlecast skins (which I'm not sure is even canon) he's been ignored.  So much could be done, and I hope Riot hasn't forgotten about him and the original purpose of his Glorious Evolution.

To answer this question: I want to hear more about whatever Champions are slated for a major rewrite, so that Narrative and the community can discuss them. Narrative says that it wants to avoid another "Great Retcon" disaster, and take care to retain the essence of Champions even when their backstories are being considerably altered; I think the community deserves to be asked about its impressions of what the essence of each Champion might be. If Riot's serious about promoting greater flow of ideas between Narrative and the community, let's start with the Champions and settings that are scheduled for major changes.

---

But whoa, whoa. Hold on a second.

If this is meant to be Narrative finally coming around to engage with the community, you can't just toss this in without explanation:

> Please don’t offer up specific story ideas – legally, we just can’t use them (the same reason I don’t read fan-fic – it’s a can of worms from a legal POV).

What is a "specific story idea"? And why do you believe that it is legally impossible for them to be discussed?

I don't think this should be just casually tossed out there. Taken at face value, it says: "Whatever you do, community, don't give us ideas. We aren't legally allowed to look at the community's ideas." That is fundamentally incompatible with the Riot design model.

So is a "specific story idea"…a draft of a story? An outline for a specific piece of written work, e.g. "Teemo infiltrates the Shadow Ninja Clan in Ionia"? A thematic concept, e.g., "I think Piltover should create a bullet train to Demacia" or "there should be a Noxian custom of giving kids their first axe for their sixteenth birthday"?

If, as I suspect is the case, this is just "don't give us drafts or a specific outline of a story", then fine. If it's "we can only tell you our ideas, we can't read your comments on our ideas or your own ideas", then this whole enterprise is a farce.

I've heard good things about Riot's legal team. I'd be disappointed if they had issued a company-wide directive to "never look at community ideas". That sounds like very poor "tell your client not to do anything because there might be a risk if all the courts in the country went mad at the same time" lawyering. I know IP law is broken, but I don't think it's that broken. Even if it is, perhaps I have a higher opinion of your legal team than you do, but surely they can put together a solution: a disclaimer, for instance, or more narrowly defined rules as to what's okay and what isn't. 

So please, explain what you mean by "specific story ideas".
